Comment: This is my fourth annotation. In this annotation I would like to show you how you can come back from being the underdog near the beginning. As said in previous annotations, I always start with the king's pawn.
One of the most common defences for this move. I was actually expecting this.
Probably not the best option. Blocking a knight and a pawn. Attacking the black pawn on e5 would have been better.
Just in case I went for the early checkmate, it was blocked.
So my knight comes out to further defend the king's pawn.
Could have played a move that opened up the centre of the board a bit more.
The bishop comes out and my pieces start to take territory on the board.
A move which opens up a queen and closes off a knight.
Opening up the bishop on c1 to dominate the centre of the board.
Comes to attack my bishop.
The only place I could move without being taken.
About to close in my bishop. This is unstoppable, so I keep playing until he decides to attack.
The defence for the knight. Also defending his queen in the process.
The defence for the knight. Also defending his queen in the process.

I castle queen side. Time to defend the king. Castling usually puts the king away and pretty safe if the pawns in front are there. Give the king a bit of room to move around though, otherwise if trapped, the game could be over in a few moves.
Attacks my bishop on the black square.
I move to still attack the knight.
If I am about to lose a bishop, I might as well take something anyway.
Tried something else first.
And to no surprise, the bishop is taken.
I take the pawn on a4 and in the process, losing my knight.
